instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-3435: What is 820-3435? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3435</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>  no lcd
threads.message:
customer was told buy another store the bios is not working, after opening the macbook I found the board was never removed
green light fan spins
backlight on no lcd
bkl 21.91v
<CHIP>U5670</CHIP> rabbit hole (why apple)
Im not 100% sure how the dp circuit works on these

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3435</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>  no lcd
threads.message: If backlight is on then the LCD is working. Removed SSD? Can you do a PRAM reset?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3435</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>  no lcd
threads.message: no folder icon, ssd removed, pram reset done, the fan did an extra spin, no chime

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3435</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>  no lcd
threads.message: Did it do a PRAM, LCD goes off and comes back on? It does sound like a corrupt BIOS.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3435</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>  no lcd
threads.message: it does a normal pram reset, but without a chime or anything on the screen

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3435</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>  no lcd
threads.message: Disconnect IO board flat cable to be sure that is not messing with anything. Actually disconnect everything besides the LCD. After that is does seem to be a ROM issue.
